bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: The Dead in This War
bibl.orgName: The Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

div1.ab: Write a piece for address to Audiences—
—there they lie, strewing the fields & woods of the south—The Virginia peninsula there between the James River Malvern Hills & Fair Oaks the banks of the Chickahominy
The bloody hills terraces of Fredericksburgh—Antietam Bridge—the grisly ravines of Manassas
—The prison-pens Andersonville, Salisbury, Belle Isle The grave yards of hospitals—
The resultsgreat crop reaped by the mighty reapers, typhoid, dysentery and inflammations—
div1.add: Hooker's battle of Chancellorsville (see description) at night
div1.ab: some lie at the bottom of the sea
—some where they crawled to die alone in bushes in clumps on the sides of hills—& there their skeletons bleach white & unheeded.
—The dead, the dead—our dead—our young men, so handsome, so joyous,
taken from us, the son taken from the mother, the brother from the brother, the husband from the wife, the dear friend from the friend
bodies float down the rivers, & catch & lodge, (dozens, scores floated down the Potomac in after the Cavalry engagements following Gettysburgh when our men pursued Lee)
